title: Asia Energy Leaders Call for New Collaborations and Partnerships to Support Asia's Rapid Growth
summary: Hong Kong - With nearly half of the world's population calling Asia home, rapid urbanization will further fuel the region's consumption of energy, which is already at a level surpassing the rest of the world. The modern energy needs required to sustain and improve the well-being of its population and its urban centers is transforming the energy landscape in the region.
tag-1: Asia Energy Leaders Call for New Collaborations and Partnerships to Support Asia's Rapid Growth
tag-3: Hong Kong – With nearly half of the world's population calling Asia home, rapid urbanization will further fuel the region's consumption of energy, which is already at a level surpassing the rest of the world. The modern energy needs required to sustain and improve the well-being of its population and its urban centers is transforming the energy landscape in the region.
tag-4: Today, the FT/Citi Ingenuity Awards Energy Forum brought together leading experts to enable a closer look at the landscape in Asia with the goal of uncovering ways to accelerate energy innovation. The event featured leading corporate experts from a range of companies, NGOs, and academic institutions who explored trends in classic and alternative energy sources, energy innovation, and the most impactful sustainable practices.
tag-5: "Innovation is essential for Asia's economies, businesses and citizens to manage the challenges ahead and to capitalize on the opportunities from urbanization. For its cities and people to continue to thrive, all stakeholders – from large multinationals to policymakers and entrepreneurs – must explore disruptive strategies and solutions to meet the region's growing energy demand that harness efficiencies and manage costs," said Bruce Schlein, Director, Corporate Sustainability, Citi.
tag-6: "Every jurisdiction has to decide on what is their future fuel mix for their energy needs. This is as much a political as a business or technology issue. Going from a 'brown' to a 'green' economy requires making tough choices," said Christine Loh, CEO, Civic Exchange.
tag-7: "The past two-decades have witnessed a great accumulation of experience, knowledge and know-how of sustainable urban management around the world," said Changhua Wu, Greater China Director, The Climate Group. "From planning and design to infrastructure, from financing to innovation, city managers today have more to share than ever as demonstrated at the just concluded Rio+20 UN Summit on sustainable development. The rapid urbanization in Asia presents the greatest opportunity ever for city managers to do it right now to avoid the lock-in consequences in both energy and resource consumption and emissions of carbon and other pollutants. Better City Better Life was the vision for the Shanghai World Expo in 2010 but shall become a reality in Asia if we adopt an integrated solutions in urban management. Redesign is the trend and a right strategy to achieve the aspiration of billions of people in Asia."

tag-9: The forum, the first in a series of conferences, is part of the FT/Citi Ingenuity Awards, a global program, sponsored by Citi, developed to recognize individuals whose solutions are fueling growth and economic progress in cities around the world.
tag-10: With its global footprint built over 200 years, Citi has a unique perspective on the complexities of the urban environment. Through Citi for Cities and other initiatives, Citi works with clients and partners around the world in both the public and private sectors to enhance energy efficiencies, facilitate utility management and finance innovative and sustainable energy solutions.
tag-11: FT/Citi Ingenuity Awards: Recognizing Solutions Fueling Economic Progress
tag-12: More than half the world's population lives in cities today, a number which is expected to rise in the decades ahead. As a result, cities have a pressing need to address the challenges of urbanization and find solutions that modernize infrastructure, improve efficiency, enhance quality of life and foster sustainable growth and development.
tag-13: Citi has joined with the Financial Times to sponsor the FT/Citi Ingenuity Awards: Urban Ideas in Action. The global program recognizes individuals who have developed groundbreaking solutions to urban challenges that benefit cities, citizens and urban communities in the fields of education, energy, healthcare and infrastructure.
tag-14: Criteria and metrics for the Awards have been developed by INSEAD, one of the world's leading and largest graduate business schools. All entries will be reviewed by the FT and INSEAD for qualification. A panel of industry leaders will select finalists and winners. As sponsor, Citi will not review or judge submissions.
tag-15: Category finalists will be profiled in a series of Financial Times global magazines. A global winner and category winners will be announced in December 2012.
tag-16: "As demand for energy is intensifying, particularly in Asia, we hope that today's forum, part of the FT/Citi Ingenuity Awards program, helps contribute to the important dialogue about the future of energy in the region," said Shengman Zhang, Citi Country Officer, Hong Kong. "By embracing transformation, cities can improve both citizens' quality of life and their prospects in the competition for talent and investment."

tag-19: Citi for Cities Citi for Cities is an initiative that harnesses the best of Citi across the globe to enable cities to become more efficient, by providing financing that facilitates commerce and modernization, and by empowering citizens to access services that enhance liveability and prosperity. Citi aims to help cities achieve their ambitions across the key ecosystems that power a city including administration, roads and transit, ports of entry, energy and utilities, workplace and education, health and safety and regeneration and development. Citi's span of engagement with cities includes public and private sectors, the financial sector and citizens and the communities in which they live.
